Key Arguments: The bill is seen as Orwellian and an assault on free speech.
The legislation is too broad and could lead to censorship on general issues.
Controlling misinformation on public health or the environment is viewed as authoritarian.
There is concern over who decides what constitutes misinformation.
Historical examples are provided where initially dismissed misinformation was later accepted as true.
The potential harm of the legislation is seen as greater than the harm it seeks to prevent.
Main Themes: Historical examples of misinformation becoming accepted truth
